text: Sirolimus is an immunosuppressive drug used to prevent graft rejection.
label: Drug

text: Therapeutic drug monitoring is required as with other immunosuppressive drugs.
Previous studies have shown the interactions between sirolimus and drugs that affect the activity of cytochrome P450 3A4 and P-glycoprotein.
label: Drug

text: There is an increasing tendency for the use of herbal remedies in many countries.
Medicinal herbs are rich sources of natural bioactive compounds that could interact with drugs.
Parsley, Petroselinum crispum, is a food, spice, and also a medicinal herb.
label: Herb name
Herb name

text: We report a case of a renal transplant recipient who had a supratherapeutic blood level of sirolimus due to consuming excessive parsley to highlight a possible herb–drug interaction.
label: Drug

text: This is the first case report describing sirolimus–parsley interaction.
label: Drug
Herb name

text: Herb–drug interactions are especially important for drugs with a narrow therapeutic window.
For this reason, healthcare professionals should question all patients, especially transplant patients, about the use of herbs or herbal products and report interactions.

Parsley, a commonly consumed food, affects the level of an important drug in a renal transplant recipient: A case report  Sirolimus is a drug that suppresses the immune response used to prevent organ rejection in people who have had kidney transplants.
label: Herb name
Drug

text: In order to reach the optimum balance between therapeutic efficacy and adverse effects, sirolimus blood levels should be closely monitored.
label: Pathology
Drug

text: Previous studies have shown the interactions between sirolimus and drugs that affect the activities of metabolizing enzymes and transporter proteins.
label: Drug

text: Parsley is a food, spice, and also a medicinal herb.
label: Herb name

text: Medicinal herbs are rich sources of natural bioactive compounds that could interact with a prescription drug.
We report a case of a renal transplant recipient who had a rise in the blood level of sirolimus due to the ingestion of an excessive amount of parsley to highlight possible herb–drug interaction.
label: Drug
Herb name

text: Sirolimus, a macrolide compound isolated from Streptomyces hygroscopicus, was introduced in the late 1990s.
label: Drug

text: The demonstration of the potent immunosuppressive activity of sirolimus has led to its usage for the prevention of graft rejection in kidney transplantation.
label: Drug
Pathology

text: Sirolimus binds to a protein (FK binding protein-12) and this complex inhibits the activation of the mammalian target of rapamycin, which is a key regulatory kinase for cell cycle progression, thus suppressing cytokine-driven T-cell proliferation.
label: Drug

text: Sirolimus displays a synergistic action with calcineurin inhibitors and a distinctive mechanism of action from calcineurin inhibitors, which are indispensable immunosuppressive agents in kidney transplantation.
label: Drug
Drug
Drug

text: In addition, sirolimus has some advantages compared with calcineurin inhibitors: sirolimus causes less nephrotoxicity, has anticancer effects, and allows once-daily administration.
label: Drug
Drug
Drug
Pathology

text: In recent years, the increasing use of herbs and herbal medicines for primary healthcare and chronic diseases has been widely reported in many countries.

One of the important safety concerns with the widespread herbal remedy use is the potential interactions of herbal medicines with prescription drugs that may augment or inhibit the effect of the drugs.
This is especially important for drugs with a narrow therapeutic window.
Parsley, Petroselinum crispum, is commonly consumed as part of the diet.
label: Herb name
Herb name

text: Parsley, which is also a medicinal herb, is stated to have carminative, antispasmodic, diuretic, emmenagogue, expectorant, antirheumatic, and antimicrobial properties.
label: Herb name

text: The drug interaction probability scale (DIPS) is a tool to assess the causal relationship between interactions and adverse events.
DIPS consists of 10 questions each with three response options to which a score is assigned.
PubMed database and Google Scholar were searched using the key terms ‘parsley’, ‘sirolimus’, and ‘herb–drug interaction’ up to 15 October 2020.
label: Herb name
Drug

text: Articles published in the English language were reviewed.
Herein, we report a possible interaction between parsley and sirolimus in a kidney transplant patient leading to supratherapeutic blood concentrations of sirolimus.
label: Herb name
Drug
Drug

text: A 19-year-old woman was diagnosed with chronic kidney disease secondary to juvenile nephronophthisis.
label: Age
Sex
Pathology

text: In 2013, the patient underwent renal transplantation from her mother.
Postrenal transplantation immunosuppressive therapy of the patient comprised a triple drug combination of prednisolone, tacrolimus, and mycophenolate mofetil.
label: Drug
Drug
Drug

text: The patient’s medical history included pseudotumor cerebri and hypophosphatemic rickets.
Her other significant medications included enalapril 10 mg once daily, calcitriol 0.5 µg once daily, and 1000 mg elemental phosphorus containing effervescent tablet twice daily.
label: Drug
Amount
Frequency
Drug
Amount
Frequency
Amount
Frequency

text: The patient received tacrolimus-based immunosuppression until April 2016, and then the treatment was switched from tacrolimus to sirolimus due to evident tremors.
label: Drug
Drug
Drug
Pathology

text: Immunosuppressive treatment of the patient was under control with sirolimus 1.5 mg twice daily, mycophenolate mofetil 540 mg twice daily, and prednisolone 10 mg once daily since 2016.
label: Drug
Amount
Frequency
Drug
Amount
Frequency
Drug
Amount
Frequency

text: In July 2020 at an out-patient follow-up visit, the patient’s blood level of sirolimus (14.8 ng/ml) was seen to be high.
label: Drug
Amount

text: Previous blood sirolimus levels ranged from 2 ng/ml to 4 ng/ml.
label: Drug
Amount
Amount

text: The concentration–time profile is shown in Figure 1.
At that time the serum creatinine level was 74.27 µmol/L and was stable.
label: Parameter
Amount

text: Other factors that could increase the sirolimus level were questioned and ruled out.
label: Drug

text: No new drug that could influence the sirolimus levels had been administered.
label: Drug

text: The next day testing of the blood sirolimus level (14.6 ng/ml) confirmed that there was no laboratory mistake.
label: Drug
Amount

text: A more detailed history was taken from the patient.
It was learned that she regularly made a juice of parsley and consumed the parsley juice daily to lose weight and promote her health.
label: Extraction process
Extraction process
Frequency

text: The juice, which contained about 30 g of parsley, was consumed by the patient for 7 days.
label: Amount
Herb name
Duration

text: Sirolimus blood concentration versus time.
label: Drug

text: She was asked to pay attention to a balanced diet and avoid consuming excessive amounts of a single vegetable, fruit, and herb for a week.
A week later, the patient’s sirolimus level (4.6 ng/ml) was seen in the normal range.
label: Drug
Amount

text: No alternative causes for the rise in sirolimus exposure were found.
label: Drug

text: Assessment with DIPS was found to be five, which showed this interaction to be probable.

In addition, the patient’s low-density lipoprotein and triglyceride levels showed a spontaneous decline by 6% and 17%, respectively, 3 months after the peak level of sirolimus, which implied that sirolimus levels were associated with an elevation in cholesterol and triglyceride.
label: Parameter
Drug
Drug
Parameter
Parameter

text: The probability of this reaction to sirolimus is ‘probable’ based on Liverpool Adverse Drug Reaction Causality Assessment Tool.
label: Drug

text: In this patient, we reported the possible effect of parsley juice on the level of sirolimus.
label: Herb name
Drug

text: We propose that in this patient blood concentration of sirolimus increased because of the parsley juice she had used intensively to lose weight.
label: Drug
Extraction process

text: The normalization of the drug level when parsley juice was stopped also supports this consideration.
label: Extraction process

text: In addition, DIPS was performed and expert opinions were received.
According to these data the probability of herb–drug interaction is reasonable.
Experimental animal and clinical data have shown that sirolimus is a critical-dose drug requiring therapeutic drug monitoring to minimize drug-related toxicities and maximize efficacy.
label: Drug

text: For this reason, close therapeutic drug monitoring is recommended for sirolimus, which has a narrow therapeutic window similar to other immunosuppressive drugs.
label: Drug

text: Some known inhibitors of CYP3A4 and P-gp, such as voriconazole, Due to being natural, herbs and herbal products are thought safer and more efficacious than pharmaceutically derived medications.
label: Target
Target
Drug

text: Contrary to this safety perception, herb–drug interactions could lead to serious adverse effects.
label: Pathology

text: There are a few studies that state interactions between sirolimus and herbs.
label: Drug

text: A phase I study reported grapefruit juice increased sirolimus AUC approximately 350%.
label: Extraction process
Drug
Parameter

text: The pharmacological and toxicological properties of parsley are primarily associated with the volatile oil (apiole, myristicin), flavonoid, and furanocoumarin constituents.
label: Herb name
Herb name
Herb name
Herb name

text: Herb–drug interactions could represent a serious clinical problem during the management of patients treated with some drugs.
These interactions, which could lead to drug toxicity or graft function loss, are especially important for some special patient populations like transplant patients.
There is a lack of clinical research assessing the efficacy and safety of medicinal herbs including parsley.
label: Herb name

text: Parsley should not be consumed in a quantity that markedly exceeds the amounts used in a regular diet, as excessive ingestion may result in drug interactions and toxicity.
label: Herb name

text: There is little known about herb–drug interactions so it is logical to be alert about medicinal herbs and herbal supplementations that may have pharmacological effects.
Further researches, including prospective studies on medicinal herbs, are needed to investigate interactions with drugs.
Author contributions: MK drafted the initial and final versions of the manuscript.
MSA drafted the initial version of the manuscript.
NSK provided intellectual review of the manuscript as well as involvement in the care of this patient.
TY, SRY, and YE were involved in patient care as nephrologists and contributed towards the intellectual review of the manuscript.
Conflict of interest statement: The authors declare that there is no conflict of interest.
Funding: The authors received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
Informed consent: Written informed consent for patient information was provided by the patient.
